utterances: I know - are you also involved in evictions?
Yes, I am.
That's another example when the economy is going well a landlord may give some tenants more leeway, allow them more time to pay the rents.
But getting back to your topic, Neal, of the foreclosure mess, banks are not being so friendly in allowing the mortgage holder, the landlord to pay the mortgage late.
The tenant may lose his job, may have a financial problem.
So it is a domino effect in the landlord-tenant arena as well.
And I guess, in a lot of ways, your job is about - well, you're involved in a lot of disputes about money and other real goods from time to time - a lot of the time in fact.
So, as times get harder, I guess you'd expect people to become more, well, anxious.
Yes, exactly.

And oftentimes, an attorney who helps consumers, helps the business owner, we only get involved when there's a problem, when there is - if people can work out their problems, can settle them, can get along, you don't need an attorney.
You only need me at the last minute.
And I also know that you're a guy with a shingle out, you're very small company.
I wonder, do you think lawyers in very fancy firms with big offices to support, do you think they may be having problem, too?
I would think so because - I mean, I've been self-employed, a small firm on my own my entire 17-year career that the bigger firms, I'm guessing, maybe they are facing some small economic downtime.
That the bigger, well-heeled clients may not be able to pay on time, but I'm sure they are - the bigger firms are still doing fine.
Uh-huh.
I also - I don't know how much divorce work you do, but one assumes again as times get hard, fights that may already be bitter could get even more bitter.
Yes, exactly.
Divorce can get ugly.
And then there's issues, at least in California, I'm a California attorney only.
But we're a community properties state, so, you know, both husband and wife are liable for the car.
Both husband and wife are liable for the Nordstrom credit card.
So, again, people are going to be really concerned about who owes what and then exactly what's happening with their money.
Exactly.
Chad, is it a little depressing?
I know business is good, but, you know, you have to worry sometimes.
Yes.
Yes, it is depressing.
I have hope.
I'm optimistic.
I think there's good in people.
I think the economy is moving forward, and I think we're all going to get through this.
Well, thank you for that, Chad, and we appreciate it.
And if we need help in Pasadena, we know who to go to.
Thank you very much.
Chad Pratt, a lawyer in Pasadena, California, with us today from the studios of member station KPCC in Pasadena.
Let's get Chuck(ph) on the line.
Chuck is calling us from Bethlehem, Pennsylvania.
Hi, Neal.
Hi.
I work for a barter company.
A barter company?
A company that brokers barter deals between businesses.
As cash becomes less available to small business, barter becomes more and more attractive.
And what kind of deals are you brokering, for example?
Well, the tire guy who wants to go on vacation, he basically becomes a member of the group and then he calls up a barter broker.
The barter broker then finds a member who does vacations, and now he's trading for vacation.
But we don't do direct trade.
We - since we do a brokerage program, the pizza guy who would have to trade a whole lot of pizza to a tire guy and take it to direct trade.
Now, he can go through a broker and everybody is happy.
So this is a very sophisticated way.
I'm assuming you're using technology, computers and that sort of thing.
Absolutely.
It's very much like a bank.
You have a barter account and you write barter checks to other barter members, and it goes back and forth from everybody's account.
Twenty-first century barter, who thought it would come back?
Yeah.
Well, it's - what, the second oldest type of commerce.
I suspect you may be right about that.
Chuck, thanks very much and continued good luck to you.
Thank you.
So long.
Let's see if we can go now to Elizabeth(ph).
Elizabeth is calling us from Libertyville in Illinois.
Hi.
Hi, Elizabeth.
Hi.
Well, I work at a public library, and we've just been so busy the last - like the last month has just skyrocketed.
Really?
Yeah.
I mean, well…
Is it just that people coming in to borrow or you're issuing new cards and that sort of thing.
Both.
Both.
And our circulation number charted way up.
Wow.
Yeah.
So borders losses, your gain.
It certainly is.
And is this a good thing, do you think?
Well, from my point of view, it's a really good thing because we have all these services to offer and some people don't use them and we want them to use them.
And it justifies your existence.
I'm sure you can now tell…
That is true, too.
…the city manager there in Libertyville, they'll see how many people we have, we have open to more libraries.
(Soundbite of laughter)
We are going to open a new library, but it's not for that reason.
Not for that reason.
And, by the way, any particular category of books that's going particularly strongly?
